entry.title: Given Enough Eyeballs, All Bugs Are Shallow.
entry.content: “Given enough eyeballs, all bugs are shallow.” – Linus Torvalds – Linus’s Law

entry.title: There Is No End to What Can Be Accomplished if You Don’t Care Who Gets the Credit.
entry.content: “There is no end to what can be accomplished if you don’t care who gets the credit.” – Art Rennison

entry.title: A Bad Website Is Like a Grumpy Salesperson.
entry.content: “Any simple problem can be made insoluble if enough meetings are held to discuss it.” – Mitchell’s Law of Committees

entry.title: You're Bound to Be Unhappy if You Optimize Everything.
entry.content: “You’re bound to be unhappy if you optimize everything.” – Donald E. Knuth

entry.title: The Trouble With Programmers Is That You Can Never Tell What a Programmer Is Doing Until It's Too Late.
entry.content: “The trouble with programmers is that you can never tell what a programmer is doing until it’s too late.” – Seymour Cray

entry.title: Work Expands So as to Fill the Time Available for Its Completion.
entry.content: “Work expands so as to fill the time available for its completion.” – Parkinson’s Law

entry.title: Crash Programs Fail Because They Are Based on the Theory That, With Nine Women Pregnant, You Can Get a Baby a Month.
entry.content: “Crash programs fail because they are based on the theory that, with nine women pregnant, you can get a baby a month.” – Wernher von Braun

entry.title: When the Final Design Seems Too Simple for the Amount of Work You've Put in, Then You Know You're Done.
entry.content: “When the final design seems too simple for the amount of work you’ve put in, then you know you’re done.” – Brady Clark

entry.title: When in Doubt, Leave It Out.
entry.content: “When in doubt, leave it out.” — Joshua Bloch

entry.title: This Is Where Programming Ends, and the Real Detective Work Begins.
entry.content: “This is where programming ends, and the real detective work begins.” – Phillip Winter

entry.title: There Is Absolutely No Reason to Make Computers as Stupid as People Are.
entry.content: “There is absolutely no reason to make computers as stupid as people are.” – Nigel Jacob

entry.title: There Are Thousands of Ways to Mess Up or Damage Software Projects, and Only a Few Ways to Do Them Well.
entry.content: “There are thousands of ways to mess up or damage software projects, and only a few ways to do them well.” – Capers Jones

entry.title: The Whole Point of Getting Things Done Is Knowing What to Leave Undone.
entry.content: “The whole point of getting things done is knowing what to leave undone.” — Oswald Chambers

entry.title: The Unavoidable Price of Reliability Is Simplicity.
entry.content: “The unavoidable price of reliability is simplicity.” – C. A. R. Hoare

entry.title: The Ultimate Management Sin Is Wasting People's Time.
entry.content: “The ultimate management sin is wasting people’s time.” – T. DeMarco and T. Lister

entry.title: The Trick Is to Fix the Problem You Have, Rather Than the Problem You Want.
entry.content: “The trick is to fix the problem you have, rather than the problem you want.” — Bram Cohen

entry.title: The Structure of a Software System Will Reflect the Communication Structure of the Team That Built It
entry.content: “The structure of a software system will reflect the communication structure of the team that built it” – Melvin Conway – Conway’s Law

entry.title: The Purpose of Software Engineering Is to Control Complexity, Not to Create It.
entry.content: “The purpose of software engineering is to control complexity, not to create it.” – Pamela Zave

entry.title: The Most Important Skill of a Manager Is to Know When to Kill Your Own Project.
entry.content: “The most important skill of a manager is to know when to kill your own project.” – Keith Rowe

entry.title: The Most Important Single Aspect of Software Development Is to Be Clear About What You Are Trying to Build.
entry.content: “The most important single aspect of software development is to be clear about what you are trying to build.” – Bjarne Stroustrup
